## Study 1: Wirst-worn wearable sensor validation

\begincols
  \begincol{.72\textwidth}
  
```{r , echo = FALSE, out.width = "150px",fig.align="left"}

\fontsize{7pt}{10}\selectfont
>- **Goal**: evaluating the accuracy of the E4 in measuring HRV and skin conductance over 9 conditions widely used in stress reactivity studies (3min each)

- **Participants**: 40 healthy volunteers (19f, 30.2 ± 12.7y)

- **References**: ECG, finger skin conductance

```

  \endcol

\fontsize{6pt}{10}\selectfont
- HRV measures are affected by wrist movements, cognitive & emotional stress, nonstationarity, and larger wrist circumferences (BMI)

- **Seated rest** (with no prior stress) shows the best accuracy for HRV


## Measures: Experience Sampling Method

```{r , echo = FALSE, out.width="320px"}
knitr::include_graphics("img/EJPA.PNG")
```
\fontsize{7pt}{12}\selectfont Open data & materials with ESM psychometrics: \color{blue} **https://osf.io/87a9p/** \color{black}

- \color{blue} **Affective Strain**\color{black}: "How do you feel right now?" \newline Multidimensional Mood Questionnaire \fontsize{5pt}{12}\selectfont (Wilhelm & Schoebi, 2007) \fontsize{7pt}{12}\selectfont \newline using 2 (original) or 3 (updated) seven-point VAS items for each dimension: \newline (1) **Negative Valence** (e.g., "well-unwell") \newline (2) **Tense Arousal** (e.g., "calm-tense") \newline (3) **Fatigue** (e.g., "awake-tired")

- \color{blue} **Workload**\color{black}: Task Demand Scale using 4 seven-point VAS items \newline (e.g., "the job task required to work very fast")
